revision.text:
{{short description|Genus of flowering plants, known for effect on cats (catnip) in the mint family (Lamiaceae)}} {{other uses}} {{Automatic taxobox |image = Catnip-blossom.jpg |image_caption = ''[[Nepeta cataria]]'' – "true catnip" |display_parents = 2 |taxon = Nepeta |authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]] |synonyms = *''Cataria'' <small>Adans.</small> *''Saccilabium'' <small>Rottb.</small> *''Saussuria'' <small>Moench</small> *''Oxynepeta'' <small>Bunge</small> *''Schizonepeta'' <small>(Benth.) Briq.</small> *''Afridia'' <small>Duthie</small> *''Pitardia'' <small>Batt. ex Pit.</small> |synonyms_ref = <ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/synonomy.do?name_id=134391 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref> }}
'''''Nepeta''''' is a [[genus]] of [[flowering plant]]s in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Lamiaceae]]. The genus name is reportedly in reference to [[Nepi|Nepete]], an ancient [[Etruscan cities|Etruscan city]].<ref name="mbot">[http://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/plant-finder/plant-details/kc/e330/nepeta-x-faassenii.aspx Missouri Botanical Garden: ''Nepeta'' × ''faassenii'']. Accessed January 10, 2013</ref> There are about 250 species.<ref name="efloras">{{cite journal | url = http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=122138 | title = ''Nepeta'' | journal = [[Flora of China (journal)|Flora of China]] | volume = 17 | page = 107}}</ref>
The genus is [[native plant|native]] to Europe, Asia, and Africa, and has also [[naturalisation (biology)|naturalized]] in North America.<ref>{{cite book | title = Funk & Wagnalls New Encyclopedia | volume = Vol. 5 | isbn = 978-0-8343-0051-4 | author = Leon L. Bram, editorial director, Robert S. Phillips, editor-in-chief, Norma H. Dickey, special projects editor-in-chief. | year = 1983 | publisher = Funk & Wagnalls | location = New York}}</ref>
Some members of this group are known as '''[[catnip]]''' or '''catmint''' because of their effect on [[house cat]]s – the [[nepetalactone]] contained in some ''Nepeta'' species binds to the olfactory receptors of cats, typically resulting in temporary [[Euphoria (emotion)|euphoria]].<ref name=catnip_response>{{cite journal|last=Herron|first=Scott|title=Catnip, Nepeta cataria, a Morphological Comparison of Mutant and Wild Type Specimens to Gain an Ethnobotanical Perspective|journal=Economic Botany |year=2003|volume=57|issue=1|pages=135–142|doi=10.1663/0013-0001(2003)057[0135:cncamc]2.0.co;2}}</ref>
== Description == Most of the species are [[herbaceous]] [[perennial plant]]s, but some are [[annual plant|annual]]s. They have sturdy stems with opposite heart-shaped, green to gray-green leaves.<ref name="efloras"/> ''Nepeta'' plants are usually aromatic in foliage and flowers.
The tubular [[flower]]s can be lavender, blue, white, pink, or lilac, and spotted with tiny lavender-purple dots. The flowers are located in verticillasters grouped on spikes; or the verticillasters are arranged in opposite [[inflorescence|cymes]], [[raceme]]s, or [[panicle]]s – toward the tip of the stems.<ref name="efloras"/>
The calyx is tubular or campanulate, they are slightly curved or straight, and the limbs are often 2-lipped with five teeth. The lower lip is larger, with 3-lobes, and the middle lobe is the largest. The flowers have 4 hairless [[stamen]]s that are nearly parallel, and they ascend under the upper lip of the [[corolla (flower)|corolla]]. Two stamen are longer and stamens of [[gynoecium|pistillate]] flowers are rudimentary. The style protrudes outside of the mouth of the flowers.<ref name="efloras"/>
The fruits are nutlets, which are oblong-ovoid, ellipsoid, ovoid, or obovoid in shape. The surfaces of the nutlets can be slightly ribbed, smooth or warty.<ref name="efloras"/>
== Selected species == * Some species formerly classified as ''Nepeta'' are now in the genera ''[[Dracocephalum]]'', ''[[Glechoma]]'', and ''[[Calamintha]]'' .
Species include:<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/1.1/browse/A/Lamiaceae/Nepeta/ |title=The Plant List: A Working List of All Plant Species |accessdate=June 19, 2016}}</ref> {{div ==Gallery== <gallery> Nepeta curviflora 1.jpg|Flower spikes of ''[[Nepeta curviflora]]'' Nepeta govaniana.jpg|''[[Nepeta govaniana]]'' Nepeta grandiflora-IMG 0604.jpg|''[[Nepeta grandiflora]]'' Nepeta subsessilis 1.jpg|''[[Nepeta subsessilis]]'' </gallery>
== Uses ==
=== Cultivation === Some ''Nepeta'' species are cultivated as [[ornamental plant]]s. They can be drought tolerant – water conserving, often deer repellent, with long bloom periods from late spring to autumn. Some species also have repellent properties to insect pests, including [[aphid]]s and squash bugs, when planted in a garden.<ref name="mbot"/>
''Nepeta'' species are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of some [[Lepidoptera]] ([[butterfly]] and [[moth]]) species including ''[[Coleophora|Coleophora albitarsella]]'', and as nectar sources for [[pollinator]]s, such as [[honey bee]]s and [[hummingbird]]s.
;Selected ornamental species * ''[[Nepeta cataria]]'' (catnip, catswort) – the "true catnip", cultivated as an [[ornamental plant]], has become an [[invasive species]] in some habitats. * ''[[Nepeta grandiflora]]'' (giant catmint, Caucasus catmint) – lusher than true catnip and has dark green leaves and dark blue flowers. * [[Nepeta × faassenii|''Nepeta'' × ''faassenii'']] (garden catmint) – a [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrid]] of garden source with gray-green foliage and lavender flowers. It is drought-tolerant and deer-resistant.<ref name="mbot"/> The cultivar 'Walker's Low' was named Perennial of the Year for 2007 by the Perennial Plant Association.<ref name=ornamentaloutlook/><ref>[http://msucares.com/news/print/sgnews/sg06/sg061228.html msucares.com: sgnews]</ref> * ''[[Nepeta racemosa]]'' (raceme catnip) – commonly used in landscaping.<ref name=ornamentaloutlook>[http://www.ornamentaloutlook.com/nursery/index.php?storyid=324 ornamental Outlook]</ref> It is hardy, rated for [[Hardiness zone|USDA hardiness zone]] 5b.<ref name=chicagobotanic>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobotanic.org/downloads/planteval_notes/no29_catmint.pdf|title=Chicago Botanic Garden Plant Evaluation Notes|author=Richard G. Hawke}}</ref>
